questiontext.text: Drumcondra test scores for a large school have an average value of 114 and a standard deviation of 12.2. Calculate the score below which 57% of the pupils score.
Drumcondra test scores for a large school have an average value of 95.7 and a standard deviation of 13.7. Calculate the score below which 15% of the pupils score.
Drumcondra test scores for a large school have an average value of 92.2 and a standard deviation of 22.9. Calculate the score below which 63% of the pupils score.
Drumcondra test scores for a large school have an average value of 94.6 and a standard deviation of 17.9. Calculate the score below which 65% of the pupils score.
Drumcondra test scores for a large school have an average value of 98.5 and a standard deviation of 14.8. Calculate the score below which 37% of the pupils score.
Drumcondra test scores for a large school have an average value of 95.1 and a standard deviation of 15. Calculate the score below which 72% of the pupils score.
Drumcondra test scores for a large school have an average value of 92 and a standard deviation of 12.3. Calculate the score below which 76% of the pupils score.
Drumcondra test scores for a large school have an average value of 94.2 and a standard deviation of 16.8. Calculate the score below which 56% of the pupils score.
Drumcondra test scores for a large school have an average value of 92.9 and a standard deviation of 9.73. Calculate the score below which 37% of the pupils score.
Drumcondra test scores for a large school have an average value of 85.9 and a standard deviation of 7.73. Calculate the score below which 57% of the pupils score.
In a series of drug trials, each trial has 37 patients. The drug has a 40% success rate. For 55% of the trials we can expect between 0-N patients to recover, calculate the value for N.
In a series of drug trials, each trial has 68 patients. The drug has a 60% success rate. For 65% of the trials we can expect between 0-N patients to recover, calculate the value for N.
In a series of drug trials, each trial has 59 patients. The drug has a 60% success rate. For 35% of the trials we can expect between 0-N patients to recover, calculate the value for N.
In a series of drug trials, each trial has 76 patients. The drug has a 80% success rate. For 30% of the trials we can expect between 0-N patients to recover, calculate the value for N.
In a series of drug trials, each trial has 51 patients. The drug has a 80% success rate. For 75% of the trials we can expect between 0-N patients to recover, calculate the value for N.
In a series of drug trials, each trial has 99 patients. The drug has a 50% success rate. For 40% of the trials we can expect between 0-N patients to recover, calculate the value for N.
In a series of drug trials, each trial has 62 patients. The drug has a 60% success rate. For 25% of the trials we can expect between 0-N patients to recover, calculate the value for N.
In a series of drug trials, each trial has 73 patients. The drug has a 40% success rate. For 70% of the trials we can expect between 0-N patients to recover, calculate the value for N.
In a series of drug trials, each trial has 64 patients. The drug has a 65% success rate. For 45% of the trials we can expect between 0-N patients to recover, calculate the value for N.
In a series of drug trials, each trial has 65 patients. The drug has a 40% success rate. For 65% of the trials we can expect between 0-N patients to recover, calculate the value for N.
Average annual rainfall in the North Coast of California is 180cm with a standard deviation of 15cm. Calculate the probability of a year having more than 190cm of rain.
Average annual rainfall in the North Coast of California is 170cm with a standard deviation of 20cm. Calculate the probability of a year having more than 150cm of rain.
Average annual rainfall in the North Coast of California is 180cm with a standard deviation of 14cm. Calculate the probability of a year having more than 160cm of rain.
Average annual rainfall in the North Coast of California is 140cm with a standard deviation of 23cm. Calculate the probability of a year having more than 160cm of rain.
Average annual rainfall in the North Coast of California is 160cm with a standard deviation of 21cm. Calculate the probability of a year having more than 150cm of rain.
Average annual rainfall in the North Coast of California is 170cm with a standard deviation of 9.5cm. Calculate the probability of a year having more than 150cm of rain.
Average annual rainfall in the North Coast of California is 160cm with a standard deviation of 13cm. Calculate the probability of a year having more than 170cm of rain.
Average annual rainfall in the North Coast of California is 170cm with a standard deviation of 11cm. Calculate the probability of a year having more than 140cm of rain.
Average annual rainfall in the North Coast of California is 190cm with a standard deviation of 16cm. Calculate the probability of a year having more than 160cm of rain.
Average annual rainfall in the North Coast of California is 190cm with a standard deviation of 15cm. Calculate the probability of a year having more than 180cm of rain.
What is the correct discription of the pbinom(lower.tail = FALSE) function?

generalfeedback.text:
Use `?pbinom(lower.tail = FALSE).

  1. False
  2. False
  3. False
  4. False
  5. True

answer.text: Generates n values from a binomial distribution
The number of successes or less that will be achieved with a certain probability
The number of successes or more that will be achieved with a certain probability
The probability of a number of successes less than or equal to a certain value
The probability of a number of successes greater than a certain value

questiontext.text: What is the correct discription of the dbinom() function?

generalfeedback.text:
Use `?dbinom().

  1. False
  2. False
  3. True
  4. False
  5. False

answer.text: The probability of a number of successes greater than a certain value
Generates n values from a binomial distribution
The probability that exactly a certain number of successes will occur
The number of successes or more that will be achieved with a certain probability
The number of successes or less that will be achieved with a certain probability

  1. True
  2. False

questiontext.text:
Install the agridat package from CRAN (use install.packages("agridat")). Load up the australia.soybean data therein. This contains yield and other traits of 58 varieties of soybeans, grown in four locations across two years in Australia. For the year 1971 and location RedlandBay, calculate the 95% confidence interval for the mean of oil using a t test.

95% Bounds Confidence Interval for Mean
Lower Interval {1:NUMERICAL:=18.1:0.05~%0%89050:0}
Higher Interval {1:NUMERICAL:=19.4:0.05~%0%89050:0}

Install the agridat package from CRAN (use install.packages("agridat")). Load up the australia.soybean data therein. This contains yield and other traits of 58 varieties of soybeans, grown in four locations across two years in Australia. For the year 1971 and location Brookstead, calculate the 95% confidence interval for the mean of lodging using a t test.

95% Bounds Confidence Interval for Mean
Lower Interval {1:NUMERICAL:=2.5:0.05~%0%8324:0}
Higher Interval {1:NUMERICAL:=2.87:0.05~%0%8324:0}
